B00004ZAV3|5.0|There are many Beatles compilations, but this is one of the best and probably the most convenient because, unlike others, it is a single disc collection covering their whole career. Perhaps most importantly, it is surprisingly comprehensive - an astonishing twenty-seven songs from each year of their professional career. Compilations have two possible audiences:  hard-cores and casuals. There is certainly nothing for the former, as all the songs are widely available elsewhere; only those who truly must have everything should even bother. That said, it is near-perfect for the latter; this is the only place to get so many Beatles songs on one CD, and the collection is representative and thoroughly excellent. With a canon like The Beatles', collections must have some kind of theme, and this one is interesting - it contains all the band's cuts that were #1 in the US or UK. The tracks could have been chosen in many ways, but this is more rewarding than most in that it lets one hear a good number of the band's best, most famous, and most important songs. A few Beatles albums are best heard whole, but the group consistently released its best songs as singles, and an incredible amount went to #1, ensuring a great collection. Virtually everyone is very familiar with many or most cuts, but hearing them chronologically is fascinating; listening to the band change and progress is very rewarding. Anyone wanting a Beatles entry point could hardly do better than this.
0739367676|1.0|Well I did it.  Against the advice of other reviewers, I read the final installment of the Twilight Series.....and OMG...what a nightmare and what a mistake.   I feel I need to take a shower and brush my teeth and reread Twilight in order to purge myself of the memories of this awful book.    First lets recap the first 3 books.  I am not going to address SM's writing abilities.     I think she can spin a good yarn working with the limitations she has as an actual writer and I can appreciate that, no matter how many times her characters \\"roll their eyes\\" \\"chuckle\\" \\"sneer\\" \\"smirk\\" \\"sigh\\" \\"tighten their eyes\\" and so on and so forth.    Twilight - obviously the best book in the series.  Vulnerable human girl....vulnerable vampire boy.   Both insecure....both inexperienced......very sweet.  This book is very detailed very methodical in the budding relationship between Bella and Edward which is its strongest point.  I think SM did a brilliant job in conveying the angst that the characters were experiencing.  She moves further and further away from this type of detailed writing in the subsequent books and we lose that emotional connection.   The only problem I had with this book was Edward's ability to suck James' venom out of Bella when he could not tolerate the smell of her only a couple of months before.   This was a contrived plot point.  There was no reason Carlisle could not have, should not have done this.  Was there really ever any doubt that Edward wouldn't be able to \\"change\\" Bella himself after that or that he wouldn't be able to resist her blood.    New Moon - I unlike other reviewers, had no problem with Bella pining after Edward for several months.  In fact to me this was quite understandable if we were to believe the Bella and Edward were truly soulmates.   You don't recover when your soulmate leaves you.  You might survive, but you don't recover.   That is probably why I knew I would not like Eclipse, the love triangle should never have been part of the equation of we were to believe anything written in Twilight.    Eclipse - For me, this book represented the downslide of the series.   Even given the issues I had with the love triangle, I completely resented the way that Edward was portrayed in this book.   Even worse, I could not tolerate whiney crybaby Bella who despite her self-deprecating comments, continued to hurt everyone around her with her demands.   If the character of Edward had been true to himself, he would have shut down completely (he's incredibly insecure as a vampire), instead of being the noble hero that would take Bella anyway he could get her.   This book also had three or four hundred pages of irrelevant worthless dialogue, lack of plot and  not a lot of action.  Wouldn't it have been fun to actually witness the fight between the newborns and the Cullens and werewolves?   But no, we were stuck in Bella's POV away on some cliff somewhere for two or three pages of Edward and Victoria squaring off in what could hardly be called a battle.    And why the hell didn't Alice see Victoria's plan when she started following Edward's scent.  A phone call would have been nice.     And now Breaking Dawn....spoiler alert......    Controlling my shudders.....Let me admit that I skimmed through this book in an afternoon.   It was just so bad.   In fact the best part of the book is the first couple of chapters.  The few massive issues I have with this book are as follows.    Sex - So the marriage finally happens, and it's time for what the first 3 books were alluding  to.   The sex between vampire and human.   I am fully aware that this book was written for teenage girls, but come on.   There was more heat in the passionate kisses in Twilight then there was in their first sexual experience which was handled as a fade to black.  Afterward all we got was Bella glowing about how wonderful it was and Edward blaming himself for Bella's bruises.   Yes pillows were destroyed, but what actually happened.  How did they pulloff the act, how was Edward able to control himself.  After reading in great detail how Edward was able to control himself enough to kiss Bella in Twilight (I think there was an entire chapter on that), SM couldn't even offer a full paragraph on their successful love making?   This was a huge let down and an example of SM's lack of writing capabilities.  She just couldn't figure out how to do it tastefully.    The Pregnancy - Why oh why did SM feel the need to go down this road?  Forget that vampires should not be able to sire children, this is a work of fiction so perhaps I could have swallowed it, but why this grotesque bloody horrid pregnancy and told COMPLETELY from Jacob's viewpoint.  How fricken weird is that.   If a viewpoint change really was necessary in what is conceivably the most monumentous moment in Bella's life; it should have been from Edward's, he was the one being slowly driven mad by selfish Bella's decisions.   Why Jacob was involved was beyond me.   It was creepy and completely disconnected the reader, ME, from what was happening.  Then to have Edward ask Jacob to act as a STUD, yes that's right a STUD for Bella if she aborts this baby, it's beyond nuts.    From a logical standpoint, if this pregnancy and subsequent baby was necessary, then the child should have been born under normal conditions following a 9 month pregnancy.   A perfect reason for Bella to remain human a little bit longer and completely logical, as the baby should have been 100% human.  Why?   Well assuming Edward's body was frozen at the point of his transformation, any sperm he would have would be human, not vampire.  It might have been interesting to see them raise a human baby in the world of vampires...maybe a human baby with some special talents.   I also found it interesting that for the first time in the entire series, SM mentions Menstruation.  Hmmmmm.....it made me wonder from the very first book how Edward could tolerate Bella's menstruation cycle when blood would definitely be outside of the body.       The Birth - Oh horror of horrors, not only is Bella drinking blood to feed the demon baby, she likes the taste of it.  And how convenient that Carlisle is out of town on the day she delivers so Edward who is super surgeon vampire now, has to do surgery on her first with a scalpel, then with his teeth to remove the thing.  Then he has to transform her...all on his own (remember all of this is still being told from Jacob's point of view),  with her abdomen ripped open, obviously blood everywhere...that delicious Bella blood that Edward has pined after for three books (make that two, he suddenly didn't have a problem in Eclipse either), and Edward doesn't make one misstep,  it isn't even addressed.  He somehow knows to stab Bella in the heart with a syringe full of his venom and he diligently bites her in all the right places.  He did everything perfectly without a hitch, better than Carlisle, we find out later.   Let me roll my eyes here.     Renesmee -   This grotesque creepy demon baby becomes Jacob's latest love interest, and fortunately for him she will be an adult by her 7th birthday.   I never understood why a half human, half vampire would grow so fast, shouldn't they age slower?   Everyone loves Renesmee though we are just told this, never shown it, and though Rosalie is seen mothering it, what about Esmee....she tried to kill herself after losing a child didn't' she?  There aren't even any intimate moments between Edward and the infant.  Stupid stupid.     Transformation - The one and only chapter I really liked in this book was when Bella finally becomes a vampire.   IMO the entire book should have been devoted to her transformation with all the difficulties of being a newborn.   Instead we are teased with some humorous first steps as a new vampire but after an hour or two (I'm not kidding), she is Super Vampire with all the control and skill of a mature vampire.   Quite annoying.    Vulturi Battle - okay there was nobattle, just the opportunity to introduce dozens of new vampires that have traveled in from all across the world to act as witnesses or participate in the battle.   There really were no back stories to these new vampires so keeping track of them all wasn't worth the trouble.   This is another example of SM's lack of writing skills. Did I say I wouldn't comment on them....too bad.   She cannot figure out a way to weave them into the plot so she has to march them in one right after the other, an inventory of new characters.  There was also the issue of all of the trouble these new arrivals would create in the small town of Forks, which was never addressed other than the offhanded comment that they would hunt out of state.   If vampires were so harmless to nearby humans, so in control of themselves then why did James Laurant and Victoria create so much trouble for the Cullens.       I personally thought it was beneath the Vulturi to show up in Forks at all.  I would have preferred more subtle attacks against the Cullens that didn't involve everyone standing around and talking, but since this Battle was never going to happen anyway, I suppose it didn't' matter.    The Cullens - probably the most disappointing aspect of this book was the complete neglect in developing existing characters that I happened to like.   Much of this is in direct correlation to the first hand narration by Bella and Jake.   Still, I would have loved to hear more about how Rosalie's true motivation for \\"protecting\\" Bella during her pregnancy or Alice's relationship, that was non existent in this book, with Bella.   There could have been a subplot involving one of the family members in danger and how the others reacted to \\"save\\" that family member.  Wouldn't it have been interesting to see Carlisle's gentle nature change if Esme was taken hostage by the Vulturi........anything......but sadly......they were just cardboard cutouts filling spaces inbetween scenes of whiney Bella, moping Edward, and whimpering Jacob.        Happy Endings - I actually had no problem with the happy ending part, if there was some personal sacrifice and growth throughout the story.  In the end, Bella got everything she wanted behaving like a spoiled rotten brat through the last two books specifically.  Edward, despite being driven near madness, bounced back and was his usual annoyingly perfect self, Jacob only has to wait 7 years to get the love of his life, a sure thing, since his imprinting will leave demon baby Renesmee with no choice and the Cullens just go on as they have.     Okay I can't believe I spent so much time writing this review.  That is sad and pathetic all on it's own.  So let me conclude by saying that like many reviewers, be prepared to have this book ruin the entire series for you.   I only hope that re-reading Twilight will help me get over it.     I have nightmares about what is sure to be SM's next book....Jacob & Rennesmee - A pedaphiles love story.   BLECH

B0036EH3XE|5.0|Despite the negative reviews for season 6 in my opinion it does not deserve the 1-star rating many have given it. Season 6 dives into the what-if and explores the lives of our oceanic 815 survivors through flash-sideways. It was a unique opportunity to see how much the characters would change and how they would come in contact with each other if 815 never crashed. Personally every episode with the exception of \\"What Kate Does\\" was awesome in that characters were given the chance to address their many flaws and finally let go of their hang-ups. I think what many people fail to grasp is that Lost has always been a character study about the human condition and all the sci-fi stuff was a way to explore that subject. In the grand scheme of things the mythology, polar bears, electromagnetism, etc. was never the point it was about people, humanity in general. Like Carlton and Lindelof have stated in the past they spent 10% of their time talking about mythology and the other 90% was spent talking about their characters in the writer's room. So if you want to see a show about character pay-off then this is the show for you. As for the series finale, it does not suck like many have explicitly stated. It's true to the series and the characters. Sure some questions remain unanswered but that's life we don't know where we go when we die or if there is a higher power.

030726999X|4.0|To those of you who aren't up to speed with Larsson's trilogy, I am going to try my best to avoid giving things away, but it's not going to be easy.<br /><br />In the last book, The Girl Who Played With Fire, Lisbeth Salander-- portrayed as being worse than the Devil himself by media and police-- confronted her very real, very human, demons. In this book, she realizes that confronting them is not enough. She is going to have to destroy them. What goes against her grain is that she is forced to trust journalist Mikael Blomkvist, even to the point of letting him run large sections of the show.<br /><br />This book even more than the previous two relies on intricate plotting and the pieces fitting together exactly. This book, more than the other two, showed unevenness and sections that needed a much sterner hand at editing. Because the plot was intricate, Larsson spent pages explaining various government agencies, how they were set up, the people they reported to, and so on. These were the sections of the book that made my eyes glaze over.<br /><br />Another subplot involving Erika Berger, the former editor of Millennium magazine, although illustrating what many women have to deal with in male-dominated sections of the workforce, was really unnecessary and moved the focus away from the most fascinating characters: Salander and Blomkvist. Even Salander's trip to Gibraltar could have been shortened.<br /><br />Any time the action moved away from that two-character focus, the book began to drag, which is why I feel that it would have benefited from stricter pruning. But was I greatly disappointed in the book? No. I had to see the outcome of Lisbeth Salander's story. Was she going to succeed? How was she going to succeed?<br /><br />Larsson has given me a wonderful offbeat Dulcinea and her Don Quixote. I may always wonder what the books would have become if Larsson had been allowed to work on them himself, but the characters will always remain: a young woman who refused to accept that everyone else was more important than she, and the man who believed her.rtant than she, and the man who believed her.

B001QOGYFY|2.0|There are some interesting visual flourishes in this movie, illustrating it's origins as a graphic novel.  The concept itself is intriguing, using an unlikely location (Antarctica) as a setting for a whodunnit style thriller, with a cast that normally can be relied on to do a decent job.  Alas, the concept starts to weaken on two fronts.. firstly, the treatment of it's star, Kate Beckinsale.  A lengthy introducing tracking shot culimates in an equally lengthy shower scene, which plotwise serves to tell us... well, truthfully it serves no plot purpose at all, other than to have Kate Beckinsale in a shower scene right at the start - perhaps to hook the people that might turn off when they discover she is going to be all dressed up in bulky Antarctic gear for the rest of the movie?  And then secondly, if we are to revel in her acting ability - why then serve her with a script so clunky you have to assume it got frostbite on the way to the location and had its common sense amputated?<br />The plot is intriguing.. a Russian plane downed in the Cold War carrying a valuable cargo, serves as a prologue to a murder in current day North Pole.  As the Marshall, Kate has to figure it out, but all the suspects are about to leave on the last plane out before Winter sets in.  The setting is particularly cool - (pun intended), with the frigid weather convincingly portrayed for the most part, and some of the frozen beauty of the scenery is striking (actually Canada, not Antarctica, of course).  The whodunit will have you guessing - for at least a few minutes.  For the rest of the movie you'll have to rely on cardboard dialogue and mediocre action scenes.  On the plus side, Tom Skerritt does a good enough job to survive with his dignity intact, and the scenery is good.<br />I'll applaud the movie for it's original setting, but have to give it a thumbs down in the directing and script department.  I'd stick with the graphic novel.  Interesting idea then, but the end result will likelyleave you, well ok, let's say it - somewhat cold.

0393327345|4.0|In some ways, reading 'Fight Club'(1996) after 'Rant'(2007) gave me a retrospective view of the genius of perhaps one of the more daring chroniclers of post-modern times.    Palahniuk's nameless protagonist's partner-in-crime Tyler Durden is in many ways an earlier incarnation of Rant, the rabies superspreader. Both are masters of chaos, whose apocalyptic vision was to break up civilization in order to make something better out of the world, forcing a rebirth by destruction.    At the microcosmic level, the Fight Club Tyler sets up, complete with numbingly functional rules, appeals to everyman's basic instinct to beat the crap out of one another in a fraternal setting, which makes way for grander and increasingly macabre plans adhering to the perverse philosophy of Tyler Durden. He begins to dominate our hapless protagonist as their symbiotic/vampiric relationship develops, with an interesting twist towards the end. Let's just say insomnia and split personalities are involved. Throw in a suicidal fake cancer-victim-support-group junkie Marla Singer into the mix, and a bizarre triumvirate forms.     Palahniuk admits to drawing inspiration from 'The Great Gatsby' in the afterword that appears in more recent editions, and reading 'Fight Club' in that light does spike my interest in the classic, with a renewed reading of Nick Carraway's obsessive relationship with Gatsby.    Violent, perverse, and relentlessly gripping.

0743297334|4.0|Ernest Hemingway believed a book should be like an iceberg. The text was the top one-eighth of the iceberg while what the reader got out of the text was the bottom seven-eights. On the surface, The Sun Also Rises appears to be a book about a bunch of rich people getting perpetually drunk in 1920s Europe. But it is about the Lost Generation. The central characters are damaged from World War One. They have no purpose in life. So they wonder around Europe getting drunk. This is also a book about what is not said between people in a situation. It is about the dark side of love. Well not in the gothic sense. Lady Brett Ashley is the epitome of the flapper girl. Women got the vote after 1920. They smoked cigarettes, wore their hair short, wore short dresses, and had causal sex. They also strung a guy or two along. They were independent. All the men in the story love Brett but Brett loves her independent. She will not be tied down by any man. Jakes Barnes loves her dearly but is the only character with enough sense to know he will never be able to have her. Hemingway was a man's man. He saw a raw sexuality in the violence of bullfighting. His love and passion for bullfighting is beautifully conveyed in this book. Hemingway wrote with such a journalistic style. But he had a gift for prose as well. He proves that just because one is rich does not mean that one is happy. Beautiful writing.

B00275EGWY|5.0|I'm an Iraq veteran.  This film offers real insight into my experience.  Ignore the fact that these guys are EOD and whether or not EOD has been realistically portrayed.  Feel what the characters are feeling.  Look at the setting.  See the interactions between the local nationals and the soldiers.  Feel the FOB-Red Zone-FOB transition.  This isn't a documentary, so correctness of every item used isn't important.  The characters do undertake actions that seem insane, but so did we.  The vignettes may seem artificially strung together, but they don't feel that way to me.  They are as strung together as the events of a tour in Iraq.  The screenplay focuses on the most salient moments; the rest would just be filler.  The filler doesn't matter.  My mind flexed blank on legions of filler moments, leaving me with a series of hyper-real events burned into my psyche.  Watch, and don't worry about whether it all makes sense together.  It doesn't.  For any of us.  That's why we're damaged--maybe forever.

B000002KXV|5.0|It's hard to believe that the 1983 Grammy award for Album of the Year went to Toto for \\"Toto IV\\" instead of \\"The Nightfly.\\"  Fagen had been producing a lasting catalog of innovative & classic rock music with Steely Dan partner Walter Becker for over a decade when he released this absolute stunner and has remained relevant well into the 21st century.  One wonders if the multiple Grammy awards given to Steely Dan in 2001 for \\"Two Against Nature\\" were awarded to correct the error of 1983...  In any case, \\"The Nightfly\\" is a flat-out classic.  Fagen's concept album offering the artist's backward-looking examination of his forward-looking adolescent fantasies entertained in the optimistic 1950s is a delight.  While a natural extension of the slick and sophisticated Steely Dan sound, \\"The Nightfly\\" is a much warmer affair than anything Fagen had done before.  Steely Dan lived in a shady musical world filled with miscreants, creeps, cynicism, and detachment - a world not yet gone wrong for the young protagonist in \\"The Nightfly.\\"  Fagen's nostalgic affection for his material here distinguishes it from most of his other work and gives it an emotional warmth not normally associated with his music.  There is not a weak song to be found and each track stands on its own while contributing to a very cohesive unifying concept.  The singles \\"I.G.Y.\\" and \\"New Frontier\\" sparkle with sunny idealism even in the face of the cold war threat (even a bomb shelter is just another place for our hero to meet beautiful women).  \\"Maxine,\\" \\"The Nightfly,\\" and \\"The Goodbye Look\\" are more melancholy affairs where the narrator ruminates on dreams of romance and heartache to come.  Each cut is a work of art.  Matching each song's lyrical and melodic craft is a level of musicianship unparalleled.  The album's personnel is a who's who list of the best studio musicians of the day.  Couple the talent with the use of cutting edge recording technology (the album was one of the earlier fully digital recordings) and you have great music that sounds incredible.<br />If you can still remember what it was like to be young, naive, and hopeful, then you will appreciate \\"The Nightfly.\\"  Heck, you can appreciate the musical artistry here even if you were always a cynical jerk, you'll just be missing out on the spirit of what makes this record as special as it is.dings) and you have great music that sounds incredible.<br />If you can still remember what it was like to be young, naive, and hopeful, then you will appreciate \\"The Nightfly.\\"  Heck, you can appreciate the musical artistry here even if you were always a cynical jerk, you'll just be missing out on the spirit of what makes this record as special as it is.

1439153663|4.0|While I found the brief prologue leading into the story abrupt (Lavinia is a young woman for the span of just a few pages, then the story begins when she is a child of 6), the story immediately captured my attention and never let go. Toward the end, the story catches up with where the brief prologue ended. Not that the ending is bad or without closure, but it's almost written in a way that could welcome a sequel - when the story closes, Lavinia is in her early 20s. There has been much death, but there are also new and young lives just beginning at the end of this story. I liked that.<br /><br />This story is so rich with characters and the harsh realities and triumphs both large and small (Miss Martha quitting \\"the drops\\" and becoming strong enough to take charge of her house again; or, young servant girls taking such pleasure in a handmade doll their mama made for them, or of getting clothing scraps \\"from the big house\\" to make small changes of color or designs in their own clothing) of life that both white/owner and black/slave people had to live with in the early 1800s. Told from both perspectives, I felt sympathy for both blacks and whites - Lavinia tells a more unique story because she spends time as part of both the slaves' families, and the white tobacco farm owners' families. As evil as some characters seemed, at least one evil character seemed to have had an ounce of kindness before being influenced and shoved a bit on his path to destruction. There is so much pain and anguish across the board in this book, sometimes it was difficult to read. Because there were such thick lines separating blacks from whites, and such injustice, there was a lot of misunderstandings and little communication: Things were not always as they appeared, which made the heartbreak that much more painful: Some of the tragedies could have been avoided. While many, many wrongs occurred against the slaves, there was also violence and extreme loneliness, despair, madness that befell the landowners.<br /><br />There was a brief respite in the Madden family, who take Lavinia into their home for a few short years until she decides what future she wishes to pursue, at 17. Sarah Madden is Miss Martha's sister, and her husband and daughter, Meg, add a bit of normalcy and more depth to the family.<br /><br />If you enjoy stories of people overcoming the odds to live life as they want to live it, this is a good book to read. I enjoyed it because it included many people's stories and different points of view.rs. I enjoyed it because it included many people's stories and different points of view.

B000SEGTI0|5.0|First, let me say that the Kindle version is the REAL version of this book, as written by Philip K. Dick, just to clear up any confusion.      Having said that, the Kindle reproduction and the novel itself is fantastic.  As an avid reader of dystopian books, I can't help but love Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?.  Much like Isaac Asimov, Philip K. Dick does a fantastic job at melding bold and futuristic action and excitement with deeper philosophical questions (i.e., what it means to be human).  This is a pretty light read (albeit dark in its vision); it's easy to get through and appropriate for almost all audiences.  In fact, if you haven't read it, you're missing out on a crucial piece of 20th century literature.  Its impact on our culture (due in large part to the loose movie adaptation -- Blade Runner) has been significant, and its continuing impact on science fiction in particular is unquestionable.

0142403873|5.0|Full review at [...]    This month's DFF Book Club title of choice is The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson   with illustrations by Axel Scheffler. Last month I didn't know about this book. It's not one that I grew up with, it's not something I found in an op shop, and in fact, I don't actually own a copy (yet).    So what is it about this book that has won my heart in less than a month?    I was first introduced to The Gruffalo by our public library system. In scheduling the girls' activities, I signed them up for today's Gruffalo party, hosted at our local library. It was a free event, and I simply thought it would provide an afternoon's entertainment in the middle of the week.    In preparation for today's event and so that the girls would understand what the party was about, I decided to check out the book and read it to them in advance. I also borrowed Donaldson's The Gruffalo Song and other songs CD and book kit.    And we started listening to the songs and reading the book. Again and again. And again.    It wasn't a bad story -- a mouse walks through a forest, meets some bad characters and uses his wits to make up his friend the \\"Gruffalo\\" so he doesn't get eaten. Except that the Gruffalo turns out to be real -- and he wants to eat the mouse too!    But the clever, little mouse wins (of course).    The book is written in rhyme. It's repetitive. There are some great (very British) words and lots of alliteration thrown in, making it fun to read. I love it when the Gruffalo says, \\"Astounding.\\" It's the sort of book that you could easily memorise. Or act out. Or both. How about turning it into a play? (Already been done.)    Really, I must be living under a rock. Either that, or I don't get out enough. Because I had never heard of The Gruffalo before. It turns out that this book is quite a worldwide sensation (or maybe that's just propaganda). The BBC even made it into a 30-minute animation, sticking very closely to the book's script.    The song on the CD enhanced ourenjoyment of the book. Julia Donaldson sings her own songs, and her voice isn't crash hot, but it's passable. My estimation for her has also risen since I've seen some over her videos. She sings and performs well for the pre-school-aged crowd, and doesn't appear to mind the losing her dignity for the sake of the audience.    I really hate the over-marketing that cheapens a good book, but in this case I've been delighted with the song and the film that came from the story. I'd recommend both highly with the book.    And because I'm still not sure that it really is that well-known, I've hunted the best Youtube videos so you can see The Gruffalo for yourself!    To read this full review, please visit: [...]

B000002UAX|5.0|Miles Davis once said that jazz records should be recorded and released with all the mistakes left intact, in order to reflect the true spirit of the music. This is what the Beatles did with \\"The White Album,\\" when they who overruled George Martin's efforts to tighten up the album and make it a more commercial product. Ragged but brilliant, with some of the Beatles' best songs ever. There's McCartney's \\"Helter Skelter\\" -- a heavy metal song before there was heavy metal, and with a wonderful bit of Beatlesque humor at the very end (\\"I've got blisters on my fingers!\\"). There's \\"Yer Blues\\" -- one of Lennon's top songs, it both makes fun of and transcends the limits of white-man blues. The song also includes a sly reference to Dylan's \\"Ballad of a Thin Man.\\" There's \\"While My Guitar Gently Weeps\\" -- possibly Harrison's best song, with some of Eric Clapton's most wrenching guitar playing. Plus \\"Blackbird,\\" \\"Happiness Is a Warm Gun,\\" \\"Julia,\\" \\"Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da\\" (check out the horn section), \\"Sexy Sadie\\" (Lennon's put-down of the Maharishi), and others. \\"The White Album\\" is in the same exalted category as \\"Rubber Soul,\\" \\"Revolver,\\" and \\"Abbey Road\\" -- essential rock albums.

1439190275|5.0|I was given a copy of this book by a friend of mine.  I echo what Knows Better stated below.  Although, I consider myself flexitarian, I eat vegetarian on most days. I too had weight loss that stalled out.   A review of my diet diary revealed that I was loading up on the high starch carbs and sugars.  As soon as I switched to the vegetarian menus suggested in the book, the weight started moving again.      This book goes out of its way to dispell some of the Atkins myths.   First, the book puts alot of stress on getting most of your net carbs (12-15 net carbs) in induction from what they call foundation vegetables - i.e high fiber, high vitamin, low nutrient dense vegetables. This translates to 5-8 servings of vegetables a day. Now, how can I argue with that?      Second, they emphasize making the program work for you and, give you strategies to personalize it.  Some people (those with 15 lbs or less to goal, the very physically active, or vegetarians) can start in the ongoing weight loss phase:  lacto-ovovegetarians at 30-35 gms net carbs, vegans at 50 net carbs.     In the same way, there is a whole chapter devoted to the role of protein and how much a person should get. And, they are quick to point out that some (petite women such as myself) must pay attention to portion size.  For example, reading in chapter 7, The Power of Protein, it is advised that I get a minimum of 71 gms of protein. This isn't hard to do:  2 eggs or 1 egg and 3 egg whites or a protein smoothie at breakfast, 4 ounces of protein at lunch, and 4 ounces of protein at dinner - all of which can come from vegetarian sources - and I've met my suggested minimum.     Emphasis is also placed on checking with your health care professional and there is a whole chapter, chapter 13, they consider you share with your health care professional.      Other strengths of the book are one week menu plans for each phase of the program - INCLUDING menu plans for vegetarians and vegans, tips on eating in restaurants, the importance of exercise and how to begin an exercise program, as well as a discussion on metabolic syndrome and diabetes.

B0039TD7RC|2.0|The Beatles catalog was rereleased in September to much deserved fanfare. The flat and tinny quality of the first CD's was replaced with a warmer, more organic and human sound. Not only did you hear details you hadn't heard before, but the music moved you in a way that the first CD's could not. That is what good sonics is ultimately about- connecting emotionally with the music.     \\"Exile On Mainstreet\\" deserves to be in the rock canon. This review is not about its artistic merits, but the sound quality. There are aspects of this CD that sound better than the 1994 version. The sound is more detailed and there is more separation of instruments- there is a more distinct sound stage. But as other reviewers have pointed out, those benefits are spoiled by a harsh sounding midrange and high end. Overall, the '94 Virgin version is more listenable and less fatiguing.     If you are listening to EOMS on your iPod or a $300 system (with flashing colored disco lights) from Target, I don't think it will make any difference. But if you have a better system and were hoping for a sound improvement similar to the recent Beatles remasters, you will be disappointed.     Perhaps some day they will issue an SACD or a lossless file version when we all have digital servers instead of these imperfect and problematic CD players.     I would be interested in hearing from those out there with turntables how the LP sounds.

A life filled with despair. Then, as children, they were chosen and touched by Jacob to become candidates to protect an island that is really a cork that keeps Hell from invading Earth (Jacob said so to Richard). Then, as adults, They crashed on that island. They lived through all those surreal events and some of them died on that island. Some others left and died a natural death in their back-to-normal life. And some of them returned to the island, became the new protector and died maybe hundred of years after. The island finally went to the bottom of the sea (as seen in episode one of this last season). Point is, they ALL died at some point. Then, they all went to purgatory and wandered around until they all figured out that they were in fact in purgatory, the character of Desmond being the one to see all that and reunite them all. The lives they lived in that purgatory is the alternate life we see during season 6, right? Then, Jack, the natural leader of the candidates, dies and they can all gather and go to Heaven, except Ben who still needs to make amends (cause that is the role of purgatory).    Is that it? Did i get it right?     At first, i thought they were all dead from the very beginning. When Jack opened his eyes at the start of season one, he was in purgatory. That explained the magical aspects of the island. And we didn't really need closure on every little detail cause it was purgatory anyway. And at the end, jack realises that he's dead, comes to accept it and goes back to the beginning and closes his eyes. I know now that this is not it. But i do wonder whay he sees the plane flying by.     But if my second theory is right, the first one i told you that is, it then means that the magical side of the island is real. Then it is a bit disappointing to not have all the answers. Then maybe yes, the writters did in fact stretched the story a bit too far without being able to come full circle with all their narrative devices.     Nevermind that.    It's easy to see that they knew all along where they were going. It was the souls of the characters that were \\"lost\\". The adventures they lived together defined their lives. And Jack was their natural leader. So when they all died, they waited for him in order to go to Heaven. Even if it meant waiting in purgatory for thousand of years.    Yeap. This is one heck of a TV series. One that will enrich lots of winter nights with discussions. Don't just bother to buy season 6. Buy them all!     Now, i don't feel \\"lost\\" anymore.    Unless you tell me that i'm so way off.    Please answer.
0525951113|1.0|I am befuddled by the numerous excellent reviews of this book - it is undoubtably the worst highly-reviewed book I've ever read, vastly surpassing Dan Brown, and a book I had to struggle mightily to finish. It started off well, then turned somewhat silly and illogical, and ultimately death-spiraled into utter juvenile idiocy.    Seriously, there is nothing redeeming about this novel at all.  Cardboard characters, poor pacing, and a plot completely lacking in believability and internal logic.  The Publishers Weekly review posted on Amazon begins by noting that the book was \\"[o]riginally self-published\\".  I readily see why - and it should have stayed that way.    Some (SPOILER) examples: If the Daemon were indeed AI, although I'd still question why it did what it did, perhaps there could be sufficient suspension of belief to buy into the story.  However, the author is clear that Daemon is not true AI, and is instead just software programmed to engage in certain actions upon the occurrence of predetermined trigger events.  Even computer games specifically designed to work in that fashion almost always have bugs in them - so the idea that insane megalomaniac Bill Gates could prior to his death write software that would perfectly predict events occurring years thereafter in the manner and with the degree of success described in the book is absurd.  As is a single hacker simultaneously directing hundreds of remote controlled cars, including his own, all speeding at 60-100 mph attacking fortified positions.  As is the program successfully hacking prisons to release gangbangers from jail, who are then interrogated by an MRI mindreading device and become servants of the Daemon that get excited about \\"leveling up\\".      In sum, this is shockingly bad drivel.  If you want to read good cyberpunk about programming gone wild, try Neil Stephenson's Snow Crash, or a good book about AI perhaps Robert J Sawyer's WWW:Wake.

0812973992|5.0|Better described as a literary work of art than a novel, Let The Great World Spin, is brilliant and profound -- and well-deserving of its National Book Award. As life is episodic, so are the interconnected stories of a diverse cast of characters that populate this novel. An Irish Catholic monk. An African-American hooker, and her heroin-addicted daughter. A wealthy socialite named Claire grieving the loss of her son in Vietnam. A Jewish judge. Computer geeks. A guy who photographs graffiti. The novel revolves around the connections -- often in unexpected ways -- of these characters with the common thread of Philippe Petit's daring tightrope walk between the Twin Towers in August, 1974.<br /><br />Part of the wonder of the novel is the verisimilitude with which McCann renders these characters. Endowed by their creator with beautiful, elegant, but clearly delineated voices, these New Yorkers practically spring off the page. They are so real, themselves so human. And through them, McCann offers a simple road map for being human: Connect. Love. Hope.<br /><br />But the novel isn't just about the interconnectedness of people; it's about connecting with a moment, a memory, an image. As the broke-down hooker Tillie wastes away in jail, she remembers a week spent at an expensive hotel with a trick who only wanted to talk with her, respected her, practically loved her. She relies on that memory to help her navigate the vicious downward spiral of her life. Gloria, a poor black woman, who befriends the grieving mother Claire based on their shared experience of losing children to the Vietnam War, explains this idea as clearly as the English language could render it: \\"I guess you live inside a moment for years, move with it and feel it grow, and it sends out roots until it touches everything in sight.\\"<br /><br />This novel is also a portrait of New York City. Spanning races and classes, it's a tribute to the city's diversity, richness and history. As McCann tells us through one of his characters, \\"The city lived in a sort of everyday present....New York kept going forward precisely because it didn't give a good goddamn about what it had left behind.\\"  And then later, \\"(The tightrope walker) had made himself a statue, but a perfect New York one, a temporary one, up in the air, high above the city. A statue that had no regard for the past.\\" For that reason, Petit's walk was a \\"stroke of genius.\\"<br /><br />And though 9/11 is never mentioned explicitly, it's clearly the undercurrent for and possibly the impetus of this novel. As people connected based on the novelty and shared experience of Petit's walk, so also did they connect on the shared and horrific experience of the terrorist attacks on the most horrific day in American history. McCann, seemingly randomly at the time, includes a photo of \\"a man high in the air while a plane disappears, it seems, into the edge of the building.\\" The photo's weird trick of perspective didn't mean anything particularly interesting until 27 years after it was taken. Now, looking at it, and contemplating its prescience, you can't help but shudder.<br /><br />This is a novel that I cannot leave; it really affected me. As I've written this, I've gone back and reread several of McCann's elegant passages. They say a picture is worth a thousand words, but for McCann, it only takes 95 or so. He conveys images, emotions, memories in words and phrases that are just so precise. For example: \\"She had the bluest eyes, they looked like small drops of September sky.\\"  How many times have you read novelists who totally flub an eye-description analogy? Not McCann -- it's perfect, and that's just one of hundreds of examples throughout the novel. I can't recommend it more highly. Please read it. Please.city lived in a sort of everyday present....New York kept going forward precisely because it didn't give a good goddamn about what it had left behind.\\"  And then later, \\"(The tightrope walker) had made himself a statue, but a perfect New York one, a temporary one, up in the air, high above the city. A statue that had no regard for the past.\\" For that reason, Petit's walk was a \\"stroke of genius.\\"    And though 9/11 is never mentioned explicitly, it's clearly the undercurrent for and possibly the impetus of this novel. As people connected based on the novelty and shared experience of Petit's walk, so also did they connect on the shared and horrific experience of the terrorist attacks on the most horrific day in American history. McCann, seemingly randomly at the time, includes a photo of \\"a man high in the air while a plane disappears, it seems, into the edge of the building.\\" The photo's weird trick of perspective didn't mean anything particularly interesting until 27 years after it was taken. Now, looking at it, and contemplating its prescience, you can't help but shudder.    This is a novel that I cannot leave; it really affected me. As I've written this, I've gone back and reread several of McCann's elegant passages. They say a picture is worth a thousand words, but for McCann, it only takes 95 or so. He conveys images, emotions, memories in words and phrases that are just so precise. For example: \\"She had the bluest eyes, they looked like small drops of September sky.\\"  How many times have you read novelists who totally flub an eye-description analogy? Not McCann -- it's perfect, and that's just one of hundreds of examples throughout the novel. I can't recommend it more highly. Please read it. Please.
B002VPE1B6|5.0|This movie is mind blowing how beautiful it looks.  With the right set up it looks amazing.  Blu-ray is a must have.
0061922315|5.0|In secret daughter, an Indian infant Usha, is given up for adoption by her mother, Kavita Merchant, to spare her the fate of becoming another statistic of female infanticide. The loss of her daughter would haunt her for the rest of her life even after the birth of a boy that would elevate her in the eyes of her in-laws.    In California, Somer Thakar, a Medical doctor, suffers yet another miscarriage, a monumental loss and a painful reminder that she will never have kids biologically. Adoption becomes a choice for she and her Medical Doctor husband, Krishan, an Indian Nationale.    Usha, later on renamed Asha (meaning hope) becomes their child via adoption with the help of Sarla Thakkar, Somer's mother inlaw. Her privileged upbringing is no barrier to her emotions as she frets that she was rejected by her birth parents. Her career choice in journalism and her temporary relocation to India on a work assignment simultaneously creates a wedge between her and her adopted mother. Somer also resents her husband for approving of their daughter's decision to work in India temporarily and feels like an alien in her family between her Indian husband and their Indian daughter.    Back in India, Asha's birth parents, the Merchants, struggle financially and emotionally. Their son, Vijay, turns out to be a disappointment as he becomes a drug addict. While Asha is accepted by her extended family in India, she embarks on a search for her birth parents and finally locates their settlement in India. The feeling of resentment and prior rejection evaporates and is replaced by a sense of gratitude that she was given up for adoption to spare her a life of poverty.    Jasu Merchant, powerless over tradtion, still mourns over the death of their first daughter by his cousin, and their second daughter, until his ailing wife, also haunted by her fate, confesses that Usha was not dead at the time of her birth, but that she had given her up for adoption. Armed with this information and the address, he tries to locate the adoption centre and there is informed that she is alive, adopted by an American family and he also gets to read the little note she had left them.    Secret daughter is the best novel that I have read from a writer of Indian ancestry. The author sucesfully conveys the emotional angst of adoption, culture clash and loss in this novel. Though it is a work of fiction, I wish there was a memorable reunion between the birth parents and their daughter.    4.5 stars!
0143038419|4.0|My, people have very strong opinions about this book. The first time that I tried to read it, I felt like flinging it at the wall too, as some disgruntled reviewers have done. The very chatty style, self-pitying descriptions of breakups that happen to all of us turned me off. Please note spoiler alert if you want to keep reading this review.     Later, after seeing Gilbert on Oprah, and now with the intense publicity regarding Julia Roberts's role in the movie, soon to be released, I was curious about why people in general liked/disliked, felt the \\"Pray\\" section in India was boring, but \\"loved\\" the \\"Eat\\" section, and liked the happy ending in the \\"Love\\" section.     So, I hauled out the book again and took another read. Maybe I have matured since I tried to read it a few months ago. But here's my second/third try at this work. Because I think it is exactly that: a good piece of work; not necessarily the writing, which can be too glib, but work on herself.     Liz Gilbert knows herself well enough to lay bare all of her faults, more than once: interrupting people, being arrogant, flirting and thinking that she is so beautiful, etc. etc. etc. If you can accept that this is who she is--warts and all, the descriptions that she gives, especially in the \\"Pray\\" section can be read as illuminating, especially for those readers who might not be interested in a spiritual search at all.     There is a benefit and a drawback from Gilbert's chatty style. It creates a frenetic pace to the book. Which we really don't need more of in this day and age of rushing through everything. Although the style is disconcerting and annoying at times, it does itself a disservice because in many places, Gilbert has something meaningful to say and she says it well. Especially in the \\"Pray\\" section after the Texan goes home. The benefit is that its super-friendly tone is one that apparently many readers need to feel at home with in order to be engaged. Otherwise, they might not read about things like spirituality at all. That's too bad, because it makes something worthwhile appear to be superficial. In this way, Gilbert unwittingly undermines the effectiveness of some of the more substantive ideas in the book which are pretty smart and well-written besides (like her description of having experienced God.)     All in all, I feel that the reason that readers liked Italy, felt uncomfortable with India, and were relieved with Bali, is because that is what our culture tells us to feel: that is, fluff and food is fine; spirituality is tough; and falling in love is a relief (except that she doesn't, really.) So, ironically to this reader at least, the intense thumbs up or thumbs down responses to this bestseller is a mirror of our society and our culture.     That's the scary part.

1600243916|5.0|I found \\"outliers\\" One of the best books,if not the best book on the subject of success ever written.Malcolm Gladwell wrote this book as a corrective and an assault on the way we are taught to view and achieve success which does not work and is dangerous.We pretend that success is based on individual merit,when in fact no one does it alone.The notion that if you are not outrageously successful you just didn't work hard enough,or you just don't have what it takes is to simplistic and almost completely inaccurate.Outliers demystifies success and helps one to realize that people who succeed in a big way are more average than you think and more often than not had outrageous opportunities to find meaningful work,and at a time when ones special talents were needed and opportunity wide open to them.like many things it is not one thing it is many things coming together.Read Outliers.the story of success.

B0036EH3XE|5.0|I think whether you love or hate the series finale depends upon whether you are a person or science vs a person of faith. I for one feel that Lost is the most perfect series ever created in that the writers saw the story line all the way through from beginning to end and actually cared about the outcome of the characters. What the end showed us was that it was the journey and the friendships/relationships formed by these people that were of true importance over the past six seasons, and NOT THE MINUTIA OF THE PLOT!!! Just like LIFE. In the end, when we die, is it going to be important what jobs we held, what our income we had, what kind of car we drove?  No, it's going to be about who we loved and the things we did for other people to help them or change their lives in some way that will truly matter. That is what Lost is to me. . . a meditation on the meaning of life. Now, I'm not particularly religious or even spiritual but I do believe that we are on this planet to make connections with others. 1400096936|2.0|The paperback edition of \\"The Power of the Dog\\" is 514 pages long. I put it aside at page 400 because 400 pages of waiting for something of interest to happen is too much. Perhaps the book would have been worth finishing (or at least finishable) if it were 1/3 the length, but it's not.  \\"The Power of the Dog\\" is a long, long, long story of drug dealing, robberies, torture, assination, shadow-government-sponsored warfare, and what have you set in Central America, Mexico and environs, and New York City. Very little of what is written is plausible; every \\"character\\" has as much depth as the typical 1940s comic book hero (or, for the sole female character, the typical noir novel femme fatale); and the narrative is disjointed and so repetitive that the story seems spare, even though it's badly over written.  I actually found the experience of reading some of this akin to listening to second-rate ganster rap (e.g., the Geto Boys): a bit is amusing enough, but the entire package quickly gets tedious. With the Geto Boys I push the off button, and with \\"The Power of the Dog,\\" I put it on the recycle shelf.
B003BKF696|2.0|While I own and enjoy a couple of other outings by The National, the release of High Violet finds the band adrift. The CD just kind of goes nowhere until Afraid of Everyone and Bloodbuzz Ohio. Then it sinks back into the doldrums for most of the remainder of the album, the one remaining bright spot being Conversation 16. One has to ask whether the band is running out of ideas. I like a lot of different kinds of music, but the hype that greeted this is surely inflated. My suggestion to anyone considering buying High Violet is to try and hear it first. Liking their previous albums is no guarantee you'll like this.

030726999X|5.0|This is the third book in the Millennium trilogy, and I would not recommend jumping in without having read the first two books. You'd be terribly lost! So, I'm writing this review with the assumption that you HAVE read the first two books. So if you haven't, scoot out of here before I ruin something for you ... but first read the next paragraph in which I make my pitch for why these books are something special.<br /><br />In the Millennium trilogy, Steig Larsson creates unique and memorable characters and crafts thrillers that are truly thrilling but also morally complex and intelligent. The theme of violence against and the exploitation of women runs throughout all three books, and Larsson doesn't shy away from the dark side of human nature. There are multiple scenes of graphic violence that will make your stomach turn, but this ugliness is tempered by the strong moral code and sense of justice exhibited by the main characters of Mikael and Lisbeth. And Mikael and Lisbeth are what make these books so compelling and fascinating. Although at first glance, each may seem to be morally compromised by some standards (Mikael's \\"womanizing\\" and Lisbeth's hacking and sexual openness), I doubt you would find two characters with such clear-cut morality and drive to protect the exploited and abused. In fact, my only real complaint with the entire series is that I found the Swedish surnames and place names confusing at times. (But that certainly isn't Larsson's fault.) With each book, I became more enthralled with the series and the characters. In the end, I'm giving the entire series a rating of 4.5. I'm positive the series will be on my list of \\"best books I read in 2010.\\" If I find another series that draws me in as completely as this series did, I'd be surprised (but happy).<br /><br />So, for those of you who haven't started the series, be gone! The rest of you may continue on to find out the scoop on the third book, which is being released today. (I'm sure you have it on preorder or on hold at your library if you read the first two, am I right?)<br /><br />Because this series is really one big interconnected story, let's recap briefly where we are at the start of Book 3.<br /><br />Book 1 (The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo) introduced us to Mikael Blomkvist (crusading journalist) and Lisbeth Salander (hacker extraordinaire). The book also introduces Mikael and Lisbeth to each other as they meet and team up to solve a 40-year-old murder and extricate Mikael from the mess of the Wennerstrom affair. The book ends with Lisbeth making off with Wennerstom's millions and realizing she cannot handle her feelings for Mikael. Her response? Take off with the money and cut Mikael out of her life.<br /><br />Book 2 (The Girl Who Played With Fire) provides us and Mikael with the back story on why Lisbeth is like she is. As with anything related to Lisbeth, the story is complicated and multi-layered and fraught with violence. And when her past comes back to haunt her when she is framed for a triple murder, no one but Mikael and Dragan Armansky believe she is innocent. The book focuses on the police's hunt for Lisbeth Salander, while Lisbeth and Mikael race to uncover the conspiracy against her and find the real murderer. The book ends with Lisbeth confronting her past head on (literally!) and ending up with a bullet in her head.<br /><br />So, that brings us to Book 3 (The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest), which opens with Lisbeth being choppered to a hospital with severe injuries, the worst of which is the bullet in her brain. Mikael then embarks on a mission with other \\"Idiot Knights\\" (those who believe in Lisbeth and work on her behalf, including Dragan Armansky and Olaf Palmgren) to redress the wrongs that have been done to Lisbeth since childhood. Naturally, this involves nothing less than uncovering a decades-long conspiracy that reaches up to the highest levels of the Swedish government.<br /><br />The book is long (576 pages ... but you still want more!) and stuffed to the gills with non-stop action and revelations, culminating with the trial of Lisbeth Salander in which her life is laid bare and her fate decided. Will she end up in jail? Be committed to a psychiatric facility? Escape from the authorities and vanish? Be vindicated once and for all? I'm not telling ... nor would you want me to. I'll just tell you this ... Larsson puts the pedal to the metal and doesn't let up once.<br /><br />One of the revelations is a physician's assessment that Lisbeth suffers from Asperger's Syndrome, which may account for her poor social skills and seeming lack of empathy. (Yet I would argue that she is empathetic to a degree that hurts her, and it simply manifests itself in action instead of sympathy ... witness her response to Berger's problems in this book for an example of this.) I'm not sure I buy into this though. Considering what she experienced in her childhood, I think Lisbeth's anti-social behavior is completely explainable and understandable. I would venture to say Lisbeth demonstrates resilience and emotional intelligence far beyond those of most people. I sincerely doubt whether most people could withstand what Lisbeth did and walk away with the the self-control and ability to assess options in a logical and impartial manner. To me, Lisbeth is damaged and protecting herself the only way she knows how ... by keeping her distance emotionally and socially.<br /><br />Although this series has always been about Lisbeth at its core, Larsson takes time to focus on the beleaguered staff at Millennium (who are reeling from Erika Berger's decision to depart to be the editor of a large daily paper) and gives Berger a storyline of her own that was just as compelling as anything going on with Lisbeth. (Let's just say, Berger finds her new job to be a bit of a hostile work environment.) In addition, Mikael has a new love interest, but I personally didn't care for this development as I kind of liked the idea of Lisbeth and Mikael someday being an item. Mikael's sister Giannini also has an expanded role in this book, taking on the role of Lisbeth's lawyer.<br /><br />I was worried how the book would end as Larsson originally planned to write more than three books before his untimely death. However, I'm pleased to report that this book ties up the loose ends and provides a satisfying conclusion to the story that started way back in Book 1. By the end of Book Three, almost all loose ends are tied up in a satisfying manner (though I have to admit, I wonder about Lisbeth's never seen twin sister Camilla), and you can close the book on these characters and walk away satisfied.<br /><br />Farewell, Mikael and Lisbeth. I'll miss you.ction and revelations, culminating with the trial of Lisbeth Salander in which her life is laid bare and her fate decided. Will she end up in jail? Be committed to a psychiatric facility? Escape from the authorities and vanish? Be vindicated once and for all? I'm not telling ... nor would you want me to. I'll just tell you this ... Larsson puts the pedal to the metal and doesn't let up once.    One of the revelations is a physician's assessment that Lisbeth suffers from Asperger's Syndrome, which may account for her poor social skills and seeming lack of empathy. (Yet I would argue that she is empathetic to a degree that hurts her, and it simply manifests itself in action instead of sympathy ... witness her response to Berger's problems in this book for an example of this.) I'm not sure I buy into this though. Considering what she experienced in her childhood, I think Lisbeth's anti-social behavior is completely explainable and understandable. I would venture to say Lisbeth demonstrates resilience and emotional intelligence far beyond those of most people. I sincerely doubt whether most people could withstand what Lisbeth did and walk away with the the self-control and ability to assess options in a logical and impartial manner. To me, Lisbeth is damaged and protecting herself the only way she knows how ... by keeping her distance emotionally and socially.    Although this series has always been about Lisbeth at its core, Larsson takes time to focus on the beleaguered staff at Millennium (who are reeling from Erika Berger's decision to depart to be the editor of a large daily paper) and gives Berger a storyline of her own that was just as compelling as anything going on with Lisbeth. (Let's just say, Berger finds her new job to be a bit of a hostile work environment.) In addition, Mikael has a new love interest, but I personally didn't care for this development as I kind of liked the idea of Lisbeth and Mikael someday being an item. Mikael's sister Giannini also hasan expanded role in this book, taking on the role of Lisbeth's lawyer.    I was worried how the book would end as Larsson originally planned to write more than three books before his untimely death. However, I'm pleased to report that this book ties up the loose ends and provides a satisfying conclusion to the story that started way back in Book 1. By the end of Book Three, almost all loose ends are tied up in a satisfying manner (though I have to admit, I wonder about Lisbeth's never seen twin sister Camilla), and you can close the book on these characters and walk away satisfied.    Farewell, Mikael and Lisbeth. I'll miss you.

B001E7OO2I|5.0|He is so smooth and continues to right things you can move too or just chill too.  He knows just when to bring in different instruments and knows when to take it solo.  So talented and his work speaks for him.

0061743526|5.0|It hardly seems like 50 years since I picked up this book late one rainy night when it was first published, after my mom had been raving about the book for weeks, trying to get me to read it.  Well, what the heck, the late movie was boring that evening and there was nothing else on the TV... next thing I knew, it was two o'clock in the morning and I had just turned the final page on what was the most magical reading experience of my entire life.<br /><br />From the opening line, \\"When he was nearly thirteen, my brother Jem got his arm badly broken at the elbow...\\" Lee hooks the reader with a deceptively simple story of a Southern family and a Southern town caught up in a cataclysmic moral crisis, and keeps us enthralled till the very last word. Lee's writing style is that of the storyteller who mesmerizes her audience telling a tale so simple, yet so compelling, that you never want it to end. Her narrator is Scout Finch, a delightfully devilish little tomboy who sees her world through the all-observant eyes of childhood. Scout is one of the most enchanting characters in modern American fiction. She's bright, funny, totally real; there's nothing contrived about her. She's someone we all knew in first or second grade, or wished we'd known. Scout lives with her brother Jem, four years her senior, her lawyer father Atticus, and their housekeeper Calpurnia, in a sleepy Alabama town where everybody knows or is related to everybody else. Lee spends the first half of the book drawing us into the life of the town and the Finch family, Scout's hilarious and problematic adjustment to first grade, and brings us into the mystery surrounding the notorious-yet-never-seen Boo Radley. The second half of the book is about the moral crisis that tears the town apart.<br /><br />Lee has a way of saying a lot by saying very little, and her laconic statement that the people of Maycomb had recently been told they had nothing to fear but fear itself sets the time squarely in 1933, the depths of the Great Depression. Times were bad for most people in small Southern towns; they were especially bad for poor whites and all blacks. In 1933 the South was rigidly segregated down every possible line, and a white woman's false accusation of rape was enough to get a black man hanged. When Mayella Ewell accuses Tom Robinson of rape, in the eyes of most of the white populace, Tom has been tried, convicted and is awaiting execution. Judge Taylor disagrees, and asks Atticus to take Tom's case.<br /><br />In Atticus Finch, Lee created what would eventually grow to be the best-loved character in all American fiction. Atticus is a loving but not a doting father, an able lawyer, and an individual of towering integrity. He takes Tom's case because he knows Mayella's accusation is full of holes, and he believes Tom is as deserving of good legal representation as anyone else. Atticus knows better than anyone else how his decision to take the case will affect his children, but as he explains to Scout, who wonders how Atticus can be right if everybody else thinks he's wrong, if he didn't take the case, he could never hold his head up in front of his children again.<br /><br />Atticus knows he's fighting a losing battle, but deep inside himself he believes he may lose a battle but win a bigger war. The chapters describing Tom Robinson's trial and Atticus's defense are some of the most powerful in American fiction. On of the most moving passages in the book is at the end of the trial when the town's black minister tells Scout to \\"Stand up. Your father's passin'.\\"<br /><br />Along with Scout and Atticus Finch, Lee created a host of other memorable characters. Jem is the perfect big brother for Scout, sometimes protective, sometimes antagonistic, always encouraging. Lee only needs to pen a few details about Calpurnia to bring her vividly to life: \\"She was all angles and bones; she squinted; her hand was wide as a bed slat and twice as hard.\\" Calpurnia isn't the stereotypical Mammy of Tara; she's a no-nonsense maid and housekeeper who dishes out ample amounts of love and old-fashioned discipline in equal doses. And Miss Maudie Atkinson is a delightful creation; funny, ditzy, and wise all at once. Anyone would want her for their next-door neighbor.<br /><br />The two major villains, Bob Ewell and his daughter Mayella, are compelling characters in their own right. Bob Ewell is quintessential white trash, spending the family's relief money on moonshine while his children go hungry. But poor Mayella is as much victim as villain; we can't help but feel for her, ostracized and isolated, knowing only her father's physical violence and sexual abuse; her attempted seduction of Tom Robinson is a desperate cry for love and affection. But, as Lee reminds us, it's all for naught. Tom Robinson was dead the minute Mayella, caught in the act of attempted seduction by her father, opened her mouth and screamed.<br /><br />After the highlight of the trial, the book might have slid into anticlimax, but it's Lee's genius that she keeps the tension heightened after the trial and its denouement, through Ewell's drunken, insane attack on Atticus through his children, and their rescue by Boo Radley. And after everything she, her family, and the town have been through, what has Scout learned from all this? Pretty much what Atticus set out to teach her all along: that you can't get to know a person until you put on his shoes and walk around in them.<br /><br />I turned the final page of \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\", unbelieving that it had come to an end. I opened the front cover and immediately started reading it over again from page one.  At two o'clock in the morning.  The book had that much of an effect on me. One doesn't just read this book; one experiences it. At best, one lives it. I did.<br /><br />Judy Lindid and housekeeper who dishes out ample amounts of love and old-fashioned discipline in equal doses. And Miss Maudie Atkinson is a delightful creation; funny, ditzy, and wise all at once. Anyone would want her for their next-door neighbor.     The two major villains, Bob Ewell and his daughter Mayella, are compelling characters in their own right. Bob Ewell is quintessential white trash, spending the family's relief money on moonshine while his children go hungry. But poor Mayella is as much victim as villain; we can't help but feel for her, ostracized and isolated, knowing only her father's physical violence and sexual abuse; her attempted seduction of Tom Robinson is a desperate cry for love and affection. But, as Lee reminds us, it's all for naught. Tom Robinson was dead the minute Mayella, caught in the act of attempted seduction by her father, opened her mouth and screamed.     After the highlight of the trial, the book might have slid into anticlimax, but it's Lee's genius that she keeps the tension heightened after the trial and its denouement, through Ewell's drunken, insane attack on Atticus through his children, and their rescue by Boo Radley. And after everything she, her family, and the town have been through, what has Scout learned from all this? Pretty much what Atticus set out to teach her all along: that you can't get to know a person until you put on his shoes and walk around in them.     I turned the final page of \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\", unbelieving that it had come to an end. I opened the front cover and immediately started reading it over again from page one.  At two o'clock in the morning.  The book had that much of an effect on me. One doesn't just read this book; one experiences it. At best, one lives it. I did.     Judy Lind
B00002496Y|4.0|I'm glad that there exist something like Amazon.co/com so that it's possible to get a rare products against a fair price. What can I say about 'the queen is dead'? It was sent to me in a short time, and the condition of the cd is good. Why not rate 5 stars? I preserve that for occasions that I go out of my head, must cry, laugh or dance when hearing it. But though that's not the case, I find myself humming the music when I'm busy doing other things. So thank you, Smiths, thank you, seller and thank you Amazon.  Frits
0061120081|5.0|What do you do when you sit down to write a book and you get it absolutely perfect the first time? Unfortunately, you never write another one. How could Harper Lee have possibly followed this up? Anything she wrote after \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\" would have been anticlimax. So on the strength of one book, Harper Lee will be forever remembered for writing one of the greatest books of the contemporary American literature.<br /><br />I picked up this book late one night the year it was first published, after my mom had been raving about the book for weeks, trying to get me to read it. Well, what the heck, the late movie was boring that evening... next thing I knew, it was two o'clock in the morning and I had just turned the final page on what was the most magical reading experience of my entire life.<br /><br />From the opening line, \\"When he was nearly thirteen, my brother Jem got his arm badly broken at the elbow...\\" Lee hooks the reader with a deceptively simple story of a Southern family and a Southern town caught up in a cataclysmic moral crisis, and keeps us enthralled till the very last word. Your father's passin'.\\"<br /><br />Along with Scout and Atticus Finch, Lee created a host of other memorable characters. Jem is the perfect big brother for Scout, sometimes protective, sometimes antagonistic, always encouraging. Lee only needs to pen a few details about Calpurnia to bring her vividly to life: \\"She was all angles and bones; she squinted; her hand was wide as a bed slat and twice as hard.\\" Calpurnia isn't the stereotypical Mammy of Tara; she's a no-nonsense maid and housekeeper who dishes out ample amounts of love and old-fashioned discipline in equal doses. Anyone would want her for their next-door neighbor.<br /><br />The two major villains, Bob Ewell and his daughter Mayella, are compelling characters in their own right. Bob Ewell is quintessential white trash, spending the family's relief money on moonshine while his children go hungry. But poor Mayella is as much victim as villain; we can't help but feel for her, ostracized and isolated, knowing only her father's physical violence and sexual abuse; her attempted seduction of Tom Robinson is a desperate cry for love and affection. But, as Lee reminds us, it's all for naught. Tom Robinson was dead the minute Mayella, caught in the act of attempted seduction by her father, opened her mouth and screamed.<br /><br />After the highlight of the trial, the book might have slid into anticlimax, but it's Lee's genius that she keeps the tension heightened after the trial and its denouement, through Ewell's drunken, insane attack on Atticus through his children, and their rescue by Boo Radley. And after everything she, her family, and the town have been through, what has Scout learned from all this? Pretty much what Atticus set out to teach her all along: that you can't get to know a person until you put on his shoes and walk around in them.<br /><br />I turned the final page of \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\", unbelieving that it had come to an end. I opened the front cover and immediately started reading it over again from page one. At two o'clock in the morning.  The book had that much of an effect on me. One doesn't just read this book; one experiences it. At best, one lives it. I did.<br /><br />Judy Lindhe perfect big brother for Scout, sometimes protective, sometimes antagonistic, always encouraging. Lee only needs to pen a few details about Calpurnia to bring her vividly to life: \\"She was all angles and bones; she squinted; her hand was wide as a bed slat and twice as hard.\\" Calpurnia isn't the stereotypical Mammy of Tara; she's a no-nonsense maid and housekeeper who dishes out ample amounts of love and old-fashioned discipline in equal doses. And Miss Maudie Atkinson is a delightful creation; funny, ditzy, and wise all at once. Anyone would want her for their next-door neighbor.     The two major villains, Bob Ewell and his daughter Mayella, are compelling characters in their own right. Bob Ewell is quintessential white trash, spending the family's relief money on moonshine while his children go hungry. But poor Mayella is as much victim as villain; we can't help but feel for her, ostracized and isolated, knowing only her father's physical violence and sexual abuse; her attempted seduction of Tom Robinson is a desperate cry for love and affection. But, as Lee reminds us, it's all for naught. Tom Robinson was dead the minute Mayella, caught in the act of attempted seduction by her father, opened her mouth and screamed.     After the highlight of the trial, the book might have slid into anticlimax, but it's Lee's genius that she keeps the tension heightened after the trial and its denouement, through Ewell's drunken, insane attack on Atticus through his children, and their rescue by Boo Radley. And after everything she, her family, and the town have been through, what has Scout learned from all this? Pretty much what Atticus set out to teach her all along: that you can't get to know a person until you put on his shoes and walk around in them.     I turned the final page of \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\", unbelieving that it had come to an end. I opened the front cover and immediately started reading it over again from page one. At two o'clock in the morning.  The book had that much of an effect on me. One doesn't just read this book; one experiences it. At best, one lives it. I did.     Judy Lind

In fact, the opening song, \\"You Don't Belong\\" has the hard-edged feel of a heavy-metal band. The beautiful, poignant, \\"Call Your Name\\" is reminiscent of the \\"is that Christian reference or double entendre?\\" approach of a lot of modern rock from Christian-inspired rock bands [It's no accident Daughtry has a duet with Seven Dust on the song \\"Past\\" on Seven Dust's \\"Chapter VII: Hope and Sorrow\\" album from 2008].  Rock enthusiasts will like this album better than \\"Daughtry\\", as they stray farther from the American Idol roots and into strong rock with great vocals.  Indeed, if there is any fault with this album, it is that emphasis, in mixing, on the vocals because that downplays the excellent musicianship here.  The band is definitely getting better at their instruments and their craft.  A worthy album to own.  Recommended.
